**Silicon** is a [chemical element](/wiki/Chemical_element "Chemical element")
with symbol **Si** and [atomic number](/wiki/Atomic_number "Atomic number")
14\. A hard and brittle crystalline solid with a blue-grey metallic lustre, it
is a [tetravalent](/wiki/Tetravalence "Tetravalence")
[metalloid](/wiki/Metalloid "Metalloid") and
[semiconductor](/wiki/Semiconductor "Semiconductor"). It is a member of [group
14](/wiki/Carbon_group "Carbon group") in the periodic table, along with
[carbon](/wiki/Carbon "Carbon") above it and germanium, [tin](/wiki/Tin
"Tin"), and [lead](/wiki/Lead "Lead") below. It is rather unreactive, though
less so than germanium, and has a very large chemical affinity for oxygen; as
such, it was first prepared and characterized in pure form only in 1823 by
[Jöns Jakob Berzelius](/wiki/J%C3%B6ns_Jakob_Berzelius "Jöns Jakob
Berzelius").

Silicon is the eighth most [common
element](/wiki/Abundance_of_the_chemical_elements "Abundance of the chemical
elements") in the universe by mass, but very rarely occurs as the pure element
in the Earth's crust. It is most widely distributed in [dusts](/wiki/Dust
"Dust"), [sands](/wiki/Sand "Sand"), [planetoids](/wiki/Planetoids
"Planetoids"), and [planets](/wiki/Planet "Planet") as various forms of
[silicon dioxide](/wiki/Silicon_dioxide "Silicon dioxide") (silica) or
[silicates](/wiki/Silicate "Silicate"). Over 90% of the Earth's crust is
composed of [silicate minerals](/wiki/Silicate_minerals "Silicate minerals"),
making silicon the [second most abundant
element](/wiki/Abundance_of_elements_in_Earth%27s_crust "Abundance of elements
in Earth's crust") in the Earth's crust (about 28% by mass) after
[oxygen](/wiki/Oxygen "Oxygen").[9]

Most silicon is used commercially without being separated, and often with
little processing of the natural minerals. Such use includes industrial
construction with [clays](/wiki/Clays "Clays"), [silica
sand](/wiki/Silica_sand "Silica sand"), and [stone](/wiki/Stone "Stone").
Silicates are used in [Portland cement](/wiki/Portland_cement "Portland
cement") for [mortar](/wiki/Mortar_\(masonry\) "Mortar \(masonry\)") and
[stucco](/wiki/Stucco "Stucco"), and mixed with silica sand and
[gravel](/wiki/Gravel "Gravel") to make [concrete](/wiki/Concrete "Concrete")
for walkways, foundations, and roads. They are also used in whiteware
[ceramics](/wiki/Ceramic "Ceramic") such as [porcelain](/wiki/Porcelain
"Porcelain"), and in traditional [quartz](/wiki/Quartz "Quartz")-based [soda-
lime glass](/wiki/Soda-lime_glass "Soda-lime glass") and many other specialty
[glasses](/wiki/Glass "Glass"). Silicon compounds such as [silicon
carbide](/wiki/Silicon_carbide "Silicon carbide") are used as abrasives and
components of high-strength ceramics.

Elemental silicon also has a large impact on the modern world economy. Most
free silicon is used in the [steel](/wiki/Steel "Steel") refining,
[aluminium](/wiki/Aluminium "Aluminium")-casting, and fine chemical industries
(often to make [fumed silica](/wiki/Fumed_silica "Fumed silica")). Even more
visibly, the relatively small portion of very highly purified silicon used in
semiconductor electronics (< 10%) is essential to [integrated
circuits](/wiki/Integrated_circuits "Integrated circuits") — most computers,
cell phones, and modern technology depend on it. Silicon is the basis of the
widely used synthetic polymers called [silicones](/wiki/Silicone "Silicone").

Silicon is an essential element in biology, although only tiny traces are
required by animals.[10] However, various [sea sponges](/wiki/Sea_sponges "Sea
sponges") and microorganisms, such as [diatoms](/wiki/Diatoms "Diatoms") and
[radiolaria](/wiki/Radiolaria "Radiolaria"), secrete skeletal structures made
of silica. Silica is deposited in many plant tissues, such as in the bark and
wood of _[Chrysobalanaceae](/wiki/Chrysobalanaceae "Chrysobalanaceae")_ and
the silica cells and silicified trichomes of _[Cannabis
sativa](/wiki/Cannabis_sativa "Cannabis sativa")_ ,
[horsetails](/wiki/Horsetail "Horsetail") and many [grasses](/wiki/Grasses
"Grasses").[11]

## History

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/J%C3%B6ns_Jacob_Berzelius.jpg/200px-J%C3%B6ns_Jacob_Berzelius.jpg)](/wiki/File:J%C3%B6ns_Jacob_Berzelius.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:J%C3%B6ns_Jacob_Berzelius.jpg "Enlarge")

[Jöns Jacob Berzelius](/wiki/J%C3%B6ns_Jacob_Berzelius "Jöns Jacob
Berzelius"), discoverer of silicon

In 1787 [Antoine Lavoisier](/wiki/Antoine_Lavoisier "Antoine Lavoisier")
suspected that [silica](/wiki/Silica "Silica") might be an oxide of a
fundamental [chemical element](/wiki/Chemical_element "Chemical element"),[12]
but the [chemical affinity](/wiki/Chemical_affinity "Chemical affinity") of
silicon for oxygen is high enough that he had no means to reduce the oxide and
isolate the element.[13] After an attempt to isolate silicon in 1808, [Sir
Humphry Davy](/wiki/Sir_Humphry_Davy "Sir Humphry Davy") proposed the name
"silicium" for silicon, from the Latin _silex_ , _silicis_ for flint, and
adding the "-ium" ending because he believed it to be a metal.[14] Most other
languages use transliterated forms of Davy's name, sometimes adapted to local
phonology (e.g. [German](/wiki/German_language "German language") _Silizium_ ,
[French](/wiki/French_language "French language") _silicium_). A few others
use instead a [calque](/wiki/Calque "Calque") of the Latin root (e.g.
[Russian](/wiki/Russian_language "Russian language") _кремний_ , from
_кремень_ "flint"; [Greek](/wiki/Greek_language "Greek language") _πυριτιο_
from _πυρ_ "fire"; [Finnish](/wiki/Finnish_language "Finnish language") _pii_
from _piikivi_ "flint").[15]

In 1811, [Gay-Lussac](/wiki/Gay-Lussac "Gay-Lussac") and
[Thénard](/wiki/Louis_Jacques_Th%C3%A9nard "Louis Jacques Thénard") are
thought to have prepared impure [amorphous silicon](/wiki/Amorphous_silicon
"Amorphous silicon"), through the heating of recently isolated
[potassium](/wiki/Potassium "Potassium") metal with [silicon
tetrafluoride](/wiki/Silicon_tetrafluoride "Silicon tetrafluoride"), but they
did not purify and characterize the product, nor identify it as a new
element.[16] Silicon was given its present name in 1817 by Scottish chemist
[Thomas Thomson](/wiki/Thomas_Thomson_\(chemist\) "Thomas Thomson
\(chemist\)"). He retained part of Davy's name but added "-on" because he
believed that silicon was a [nonmetal](/wiki/Nonmetal "Nonmetal") similar to
[boron](/wiki/Boron "Boron") and [carbon](/wiki/Carbon "Carbon").[17] In 1823,
[Jöns Jacob Berzelius](/wiki/J%C3%B6ns_Jacob_Berzelius "Jöns Jacob Berzelius")
prepared amorphous silicon using approximately the same method as Gay-Lussac
(reducing potassium fluorosilicate with molten potassium metal), but purifying
the product to a brown powder by repeatedly washing it.[18] As a result, he is
usually given credit for the element's discovery.[19][20] The same year,
Berzelius became the first to prepare [silicon
tetrachloride](/wiki/Silicon_tetrachloride "Silicon tetrachloride"); [silicon
tetrafluoride](/wiki/Silicon_tetrafluoride "Silicon tetrafluoride") had
already been prepared long before in 1771 by [Carl Wilhelm
Scheele](/wiki/Carl_Wilhelm_Scheele "Carl Wilhelm Scheele") by dissolving
silica in [hydrofluoric acid](/wiki/Hydrofluoric_acid "Hydrofluoric
acid").[13]

Silicon in its more common crystalline form was not prepared until 31 years
later, by [Deville](/wiki/Henri_Etienne_Sainte-Claire_Deville "Henri Etienne
Sainte-Claire Deville").[21][22] By [electrolyzing](/wiki/Electrolysis
"Electrolysis") a mixture of [sodium chloride](/wiki/Sodium_chloride "Sodium
chloride") and [aluminium chloride](/wiki/Aluminium_chloride "Aluminium
chloride") containing approximately 10% silicon, he was able to obtain a
slightly impure [allotrope](/wiki/Allotrope "Allotrope") of silicon in
1854.[23] Later, more cost-effective methods have been developed to isolate
several [allotrope](/wiki/Allotrope "Allotrope") forms, the most recent being
[silicene](/wiki/Silicene "Silicene") in 2010.[24][25] Meanwhile, research on
the chemistry of silicon continued; [Friedrich
Wöhler](/wiki/Friedrich_W%C3%B6hler "Friedrich Wöhler") discovered the first
volatile hydrides of silicon, synthesising
[trichlorosilane](/wiki/Trichlorosilane "Trichlorosilane") in 1857 and
[silane](/wiki/Silane "Silane") itself in 1858, but a detailed investigation
of the [silanes](/wiki/Silanes "Silanes") was only carried out in the early
20th century by [Alfred Stock](/wiki/Alfred_Stock "Alfred Stock"), despite
early speculation on the matter dating as far back as the beginnings of
synthetic organic chemistry in the 1830s.[26] Similarly, the first
[organosilicon compound](/wiki/Organosilicon_compound "Organosilicon
compound"),
[tetraethylsilane](/w/index.php?title=Tetraethylsilane&action=edit&redlink=1
"Tetraethylsilane \(page does not exist\)"), was synthesised by [Charles
Friedel](/wiki/Charles_Friedel "Charles Friedel") and [James
Crafts](/wiki/James_Crafts "James Crafts") in 1863, but detailed
characterisation of organosilicon chemisry was only done in the early 20th
century by [Frederick Kipping](/wiki/Frederick_Kipping "Frederick
Kipping").[13]

Starting in the 1920s, the work of [William Lawrence
Bragg](/wiki/William_Lawrence_Bragg "William Lawrence Bragg") on [X-ray
crystallography](/wiki/X-ray_crystallography "X-ray crystallography")
successfully elucidated the compositions of the silicates, which had
previously been known from [analytical chemistry](/wiki/Analytical_chemistry
"Analytical chemistry") but had not yet been understood, together with [Linus
Pauling](/wiki/Linus_Pauling "Linus Pauling")'s development of [crystal
chemistry](/wiki/Crystal_chemistry "Crystal chemistry") and [Victor
Goldschmidt](/wiki/Victor_Goldschmidt "Victor Goldschmidt")'s development of
[geochemistry](/wiki/Geochemistry "Geochemistry"). The middle of the 20th
century saw the development of the chemistry and industrial use of
[siloxanes](/wiki/Siloxane "Siloxane") and the growing use of
[silicone](/wiki/Silicone "Silicone") [polymers](/wiki/Polymer "Polymer"),
[elastomers](/wiki/Elastomer "Elastomer"), and [resins](/wiki/Resin "Resin").
In the late 20th century, the complexity of the crystal chemistry of
[silicides](/wiki/Silicide "Silicide") was mapped, along with the solid-state
chemistry of [doped](/wiki/Doping_\(semiconductor\) "Doping
\(semiconductor\)") [semiconductors](/wiki/Semiconductor "Semiconductor").[13]

Because silicon is an important element in high-technology semiconductor
devices, many places in the world bear its name. For example, [Santa Clara
Valley](/wiki/Santa_Clara_Valley "Santa Clara Valley") in
[California](/wiki/California "California") acquired the nickname [Silicon
Valley](/wiki/Silicon_Valley "Silicon Valley") since the element is the base
material used in the semiconductor industry located there. Since then, many
other locations have been nicknamed for similar reasons.[27]

## Characteristics

### Physical and atomic

Silicon crystallizes in a diamond cubic crystal structure

A silicon atom has fourteen electrons. In the ground state, they are arranged
in the electron configuration [Ne]3s23p2. Of these, four are [valence
electrons](/wiki/Valence_electron "Valence electron"), occupying the 3s
orbital and two of the 3p orbitals. Like the other members of its group, the
lighter [carbon](/wiki/Carbon "Carbon") and the heavier
[germanium](/wiki/Germanium "Germanium"), [tin](/wiki/Tin "Tin"), and
[lead](/wiki/Lead "Lead"), it has the same number of valence electrons as
valence orbitals: hence, it can complete its [octet](/wiki/Octet_rule "Octet
rule") and obtain the stable [noble gas](/wiki/Noble_gas "Noble gas")
configuration of [argon](/wiki/Argon "Argon") by forming [sp3 hybrid
orbitals](/wiki/Orbital_hybridization "Orbital hybridization"), forming
tetrahedral SiX4 derivatives where the central silicon atom shares an electron
pair with each of the four atoms it is bonded to.[28] The first four
[ionisation energies](/wiki/Ionisation_energy "Ionisation energy") of silicon
are 786.3, 1576.5, 3228.3, and 4354.4 kJ/mol respectively; these figures are
high enough to preclude the possibility of simple cationic chemistry for the
element. Following [periodic trends](/wiki/Periodic_trend "Periodic trend"),
its single-bond covalent radius of 117.6 pm is intermediate between those of
carbon (77.2 pm) and germanium (122.3 pm). The hexacoordinate ionic radius of
silicon may be considered to be 40 pm, although this must be taken as a purely
notional figure given the lack of a simple Si4+ cation in reality.[29]

At standard temperature and pressure, silicon is a shiny
[semiconductor](/wiki/Semiconductor "Semiconductor") with a bluish-grey
metallic lustre; as typical for semiconductors, its resistivity drops with
temperature. This arises because silicon has a small energy gap between its
highest occupied energy levels (the valence band) and the lowest unoccupied
ones (the conduction band). The [Fermi level](/wiki/Fermi_level "Fermi level")
is about halfway between these and is the energy at which a state is as likely
to be occupied by an electron as not. Hence pure silicon is an insulator at
room temperature. However, doping silicon with a [pnictogen](/wiki/Pnictogen
"Pnictogen") such as [phosphorus](/wiki/Phosphorus "Phosphorus"),
[arsenic](/wiki/Arsenic "Arsenic"), or [antimony](/wiki/Antimony "Antimony")
introduces one extra electron per dopant and these may then be excited into
the conduction band either thermally or photolytically, creating an
[n-type](/wiki/Extrinsic_semiconductor "Extrinsic semiconductor")
semiconductor. Similarly, doping silicon with a [group 13
element](/wiki/Boron_group "Boron group") such as [boron](/wiki/Boron
"Boron"), [aluminium](/wiki/Aluminium "Aluminium"), and
[gallium](/wiki/Gallium "Gallium") results in the introduction of acceptor
levels that trap electrons that may be excited from the filled valence band,
creating a p-type semiconductor. Joining n-type silicon to p-type silicon
creates a [p-n junction](/wiki/P-n_junction "P-n junction") with a common
Fermi level; electrons flow from n to p, while holes flow from p to n,
creating a voltage drop. This p-n junction thus acts as a [diode](/wiki/Diode
"Diode") that can rectify alternating curent that allows current to pass more
easily one way than the other. A [transistor](/wiki/Transistor "Transistor")
is an n-p-n junction, with a thin layer of weakly p-type silicon between two
n-type regions. Biasing the emitter through a small forward voltage and the
collector through a large reverse voltage allows the transistor to act as a
[triode](/wiki/Triode "Triode") amplifier.[30]

Silicon crystallises in a giant covalent structure at standard conditions,
specifically in a [diamond cubic](/wiki/Diamond_cubic "Diamond cubic")
lattice. It thus has a high melting point of 1414 °C. It is not known to have
any allotropes at standard pressure, but several other crystal structures are
known at higher pressures. The general trend is one of increasing
[coordination number](/wiki/Coordination_number "Coordination number") with
pressure, culminating in a [hexagonal close-packed](/wiki/Hexagonal_close-
packed "Hexagonal close-packed") allotrope at about 40
[gigapascals](/wiki/Gigapascal "Gigapascal") known as Si–VII (the standard
modification being Si–I). Silicon boils at 3265 °C: this, while high, is still
lower than the temperature at which its lighter congener [carbon](/wiki/Carbon
"Carbon") sublimes (3642 °C) and silicon similarly has a lower [heat of
vaporisation](/wiki/Heat_of_vaporisation "Heat of vaporisation") than carbon,
consistent with the fact that the Si–Si bond is weaker than the C–C bond.[30]

### Isotopes

Main article: [isotopes of silicon](/wiki/Isotopes_of_silicon "Isotopes of
silicon")

Naturally occurring silicon is composed of three stable
[isotopes](/wiki/Isotope "Isotope"), 28Si (92.23%), 29Si (4.67%), and 30Si
(3.10%), with 28Si being the most abundant.[31] Out of these, only 29Si is of
use in [NMR](/wiki/NMR "NMR") and [EPR spectroscopy](/wiki/EPR_spectroscopy
"EPR spectroscopy"),[32] as it is the only one with a nuclear spin (_I_ =
1/2).[33] All three are produced in stars through the [oxygen-burning
process](/wiki/Oxygen-burning_process "Oxygen-burning process").[34]

Twenty [radioisotopes](/wiki/Radioisotopes "Radioisotopes") have been
characterized, with the most stable being 32Si with a [half-life](/wiki/Half-
life "Half-life") of about 150 years, and 31Si with a half-life of 2.62
hours.[31] All of the remaining [radioactive](/wiki/Radioactive_decay
"Radioactive decay") isotopes have half-lives that are less than seven
seconds, and the majority of these have half-lives that are less than one
tenth of a second.[31] Silicon does not have any known [nuclear
isomers](/wiki/Nuclear_isomer "Nuclear isomer").[31] 32Si undergoes low-energy
[beta decay](/wiki/Beta_decay "Beta decay") to [32P](/wiki/Phosphorus-32
"Phosphorus-32") and then stable 32[S](/wiki/Sulfur "Sulfur"). 31Si may be
produced by the [neutron activation](/wiki/Neutron_activation "Neutron
activation") of natural silicon and is thus useful for quantitative analysis;
it can be easily detected by its characteristic beta decay to stable
31[P](/wiki/Phosphorus "Phosphorus"), in which the emitted electron carries up
to 1.48 [MeV](/wiki/Electronvolt "Electronvolt") of energy.[33]

The known isotopes of silicon range in [mass number](/wiki/Mass_number "Mass
number") from 22 to 44.[31] The most common [decay mode](/wiki/Decay_mode
"Decay mode") of the isotopes with mass numbers lower than the three stable
isotopes is [inverse beta decay](/wiki/Inverse_beta_decay "Inverse beta
decay"), primarily forming aluminium isotopes (13 protons) as [decay
products](/wiki/Decay_product "Decay product").[31] The most common decay mode
for the heavier unstable isotopes is beta decay, primarily forming phosphorus
isotopes (15 protons) as decay products.[31]

Crystalline bulk silicon is rather inert, but becomes more reactive at high
temperatures. Like its neighbour aluminium, silicon forms a thin, continuous
surface layer of [silicon dioxide](/wiki/Silicon_dioxide "Silicon dioxide")
(SiO2) that protects the metal from oxidation. Thus silicon does not
measurably react with the air below 900 °C, but formation of the
[vitreous](/wiki/Vitreous "Vitreous") dioxide rapidly increases between 950 °C
and 1160 °C and when 1400 °C is reached, atmospheric [nitrogen](/wiki/Nitrogen
"Nitrogen") also reacts to give the nitrides SiN and Si3N4. Silicon reacts
with gaseous [sulfur](/wiki/Sulfur "Sulfur") at 600 °C and gaseous
[phosphorus](/wiki/Phosphorus "Phosphorus") at 1000 °C. This oxide layer
nevertheless does not prevent reaction with the [halogens](/wiki/Halogen
"Halogen"); [fluorine](/wiki/Fluorine "Fluorine") attacks silicon vigorously
at room temperature, [chlorine](/wiki/Chlorine "Chlorine") does so at about
300 °C, and [bromine](/wiki/Bromine "Bromine") and [iodine](/wiki/Iodine
"Iodine") at about 500 °C. Silicon does not react with most aqueous acids, but
is oxidised and fluorinated by a mixture of concentrated [nitric
acid](/wiki/Nitric_acid "Nitric acid") and [hydrofluoric
acid](/wiki/Hydrofluoric_acid "Hydrofluoric acid"); it readily dissolves in
hot aqueous alkali to form [silicates](/wiki/Silicate "Silicate"). At high
temperatures, silicon also reacts with [alkyl halides](/wiki/Alkyl_halide
"Alkyl halide"); this reaction can be catalysed by [copper](/wiki/Copper
"Copper") to directly synthesise [organosilicon](/wiki/Organosilicon
"Organosilicon") chlorides as precursors to [silicone](/wiki/Silicone
"Silicone") polymers. Upon melting, silicon becomes extremely reactive in the
liquid state, alloying with most metals to form [silicides](/wiki/Silicide
"Silicide"), and reducing most metal oxides because the [heat of
formation](/wiki/Heat_of_formation "Heat of formation") of silicon dioxide is
so large. As a result, containers for liquid silicon must be made of
[refractory](/wiki/Refractory "Refractory"), unreactive materials such as
[zirconium dioxide](/wiki/Zirconium_dioxide "Zirconium dioxide") or group 4,
5, and 6 borides.[30]

Tetrahedral coordination is a major structural motif in silicon chemistry just
as it is for carbon chemistry. However, the 3p subshell is rather more diffuse
than the 2p subshell and does not hybridise as well with the 3s subshell. As a
result, the chemistry of silicon and its heavier congeners shows significant
differences from that of carbon,[35] and thus octahedral coordination is also
significant.[30] For example, the [electronegativity](/wiki/Electronegativity
"Electronegativity") of silicon (1.90) is much less than that of carbon
(2.55), because the valence electrons of silicon are further from the nucleus
than those of carbon and hence experience smaller electrostatic forces of
attraction from the nucleus. The poor overlap of 3p orbitals also results in a
much lower tendency towards [catenation](/wiki/Catenation "Catenation")
(formation of Si–Si bonds) for silicon than for carbon due to the concomitant
weakening of the Si–Si bond compared to the C–C bond:[36] the average Si–Si
bond energy is approximately 226 kJ/mol, compared to a value of 356 kJ/mol for
the C–C bond.[37] This results in multiply bonded silicon compounds generally
being much less stable than their carbon counterparts, an example of the
[double bond rule](/wiki/Double_bond_rule "Double bond rule"). On the other
hand, the presence of 3d orbitals in the valence shell of silicon suggests the
possibility of [hypervalence](/wiki/Hypervalence "Hypervalence"), as seen in
five- and six-coordinate derivatives of silicon such as SiX−  
5 and SiF2−  
6.[36] Lastly, because of the increasing energy gap between the valence s and
p orbitals as the group is descended, the divalent state grows in importance
from carbon to lead, so that a few unstable divalent compounds are known for
silicon; this lowering of the main oxidation state, in tandem with increasing
atomic radii, results in an increase of metallic character down the group.
Silicon already shows some incipient metallic behaviour, particularly in the
behaviour of its oxide compounds and its reaction with acids as well as bases
(though this takes some effort), and is hence often referred to as a
[metalloid](/wiki/Metalloid "Metalloid") rather than a nonmetal.[36] However,
metallicity does not become clear until germanium and dominant until tin, with
the growing importance of the lower +2 oxidation state.[13]

Silicon shows clear differences with carbon. For example, [organic
chemistry](/wiki/Organic_chemistry "Organic chemistry") has very few analogies
with silicon chemistry, while [silicate](/wiki/Silicate "Silicate") minerals
have a structural complexity unseen in [oxocarbons](/wiki/Oxocarbon
"Oxocarbon").[13] Silicon tends to resemble germanium far more than it does
carbon, and this resemblance is enhanced by the [d-block
contraction](/wiki/D-block_contraction "D-block contraction") resulting in the
size of the germanium atom being much closer to that of the silicon atom than
periodic trends would predict.[29] Nevertheless, there are still some
differences because of the growing importance of the divalent state in
germanium compared to silicon, that result in germanium being significantly
more metallic than silicon. Additionally, the lower Ge–O bond strength
compared to the Si–O bond strength results in the absence of "germanone"
polymers that would be analogous to [silicone](/wiki/Silicone "Silicone")
polymers.[37]

Many metal [silicides](/wiki/Silicide "Silicide") are known, most of which
have formulae that cannot be explained through simple appeals to
[valence](/wiki/Valence_\(chemistry\) "Valence \(chemistry\)"): their bonding
ranges from [metallic](/wiki/Metallic_bond "Metallic bond") to
[ionic](/wiki/Ionic_bond "Ionic bond") and [covalent](/wiki/Covalent_bond
"Covalent bond"). Some known stoichiometries are M6Si, M5Si, M4Si, M15Si4,
M3Si, M5Si2, M2Si, M5Si3, M3Si2, MSi, M2Si3, MSi2, MSi3, and MSi6. They are
structurally more similar to the [borides](/wiki/Boride "Boride") than the
[carbides](/wiki/Carbide "Carbide"), in keeping with the [diagonal
relationship](/wiki/Diagonal_relationship "Diagonal relationship") between
[boron](/wiki/Boron "Boron") and silicon, although the larger size of silicon
than boron means that exact structural analogies are few and far between. The
heats of formation of the silicides are usually similar to those of the
borides and carbides of the same elements, but they usually melt at lower
temperatures.[38] Silicides are known for all stable elements in groups 1–10,
with the exception of [beryllium](/wiki/Beryllium "Beryllium"): in particular,
[uranium](/wiki/Uranium "Uranium") and the transition metals of groups 4–10
show the widest range of stoichiometries. Except for [copper](/wiki/Copper
"Copper"), the metals in groups 11–15 do not form silicides. Most instead form
[eutectic mixtures](/wiki/Eutectic_mixture "Eutectic mixture"), although the
heaviest [post-transition metals](/wiki/Post-transition_metal "Post-transition
metal") [mercury](/wiki/Mercury_\(element\) "Mercury \(element\)"),
[thallium](/wiki/Thallium "Thallium"), [lead](/wiki/Lead "Lead"), and
[bismuth](/wiki/Bismuth "Bismuth") are completely immiscible with liquid
silicon.[38]

Silicides are usually prepared by direct reaction of the elements. For
example, the [alkali metals](/wiki/Alkali_metal "Alkali metal") and [alkaline
earth metals](/wiki/Alkaline_earth_metal "Alkaline earth metal") react with
silicon or silicon oxide to give silicides. Nevertheless, even with these
highly electropositive elements true silicon anions are not obtainable, and
most of these compounds are semiconductors. For example, the alkali metal
silicides (M+  
)  
4(E4−  
4) contain pyramidal tricoordinate silicon in the Si4−  
4 anion, isoeelctronic with [white phosphorus](/wiki/White_phosphorus "White
phosphorus"), P4.[38][39] Metal-rich silicides tend to have isolated silicon
atoms (e.g. Cu5Si); with increasing silicon content, catenation increases,
resulting in isolated clusters of two (e.g. U3Si2) or four silicon atoms (e.g.
[K+]4[Si4]4−) at first, followed by chains (e.g. CaSi), layers (e.g. CaSi2),
or three-dimensional networks of silicon atoms spanning space (e.g. α-ThSi2)
as the silicon content rises even higher.[38]

The silicides of the group 1 and 2 metals are usually more reactive than the
transition metal silicides. The latter usually do not react with aqueous
reagents, except for [hydrofluoric acid](/wiki/Hydrofluoric_acid "Hydrofluoric
acid"); however, they do react with much more aggressive reagents like liquid
[potassium hydroxide](/wiki/Potassium_hydroxide "Potassium hydroxide"), or
gaseous fluorine or [chlorine](/wiki/Chlorine "Chlorine") when red-hot. The
pre-transition metal silicides instead readily react with water and aqueous
acids, usually producing hydrogen or silanes:[38]

    Na2Si + 3 H2O → Na2SiO3 \+ 3 H2
    Mg2Si + 2 H2SO4 → 2 MgSO4 \+ SiH4

Products often vary with the stoichiometry of the silicide reactant. For
example, Ca2Si is polar and non-conducting and has the anti-PbCl2 structure
with single isolated silicon atoms, and reacts with water to produce [calcium
hydroxide](/wiki/Calcium_hydroxide "Calcium hydroxide"), hydrated silicon
dioxide, and hydrogen gas. CaSi with its zigzag chains of silicon atoms
instead reacts to give silanes and polymeric SiH2, while CaSi2 with its
puckered layers of silicon atoms does not react with water, but will react
with dilute hydrochloric acid: the product is a yellow polymeric solid with
stoichiometry Si2H2O.[38]

### Silanes

Main article: [Silanes](/wiki/Silanes "Silanes")

Speculation on silicon hydride chemistry started from the 1830s, contemporary
with the development of synthetic [organic chemistry](/wiki/Organic_chemistry
"Organic chemistry"). [Silane](/wiki/Silane "Silane") itself, as well as
[trichlorosilane](/wiki/Trichlorosilane "Trichlorosilane"), were first
synthesised by [Friedrich Wöhler](/wiki/Friedrich_W%C3%B6hler "Friedrich
Wöhler") and [Heinrich
Buff](/w/index.php?title=Heinrich_Buff&action=edit&redlink=1 "Heinrich Buff
\(page does not exist\)") in 1857 by reacting aluminium–silicon alloys with
[hydrochloric acid](/wiki/Hydrochloric_acid "Hydrochloric acid"), and
characterised as SiH4 and SiHCl3 by [Charles Friedel](/wiki/Charles_Friedel
"Charles Friedel") and [Albert Ladenburg](/wiki/Albert_Ladenburg "Albert
Ladenburg") in 1867. [Disilane](/wiki/Disilane "Disilane") (Si2H6) followed in
1902, when it was first made by [Henri Moissan](/wiki/Henri_Moissan "Henri
Moissan") and [Samuel Smiles](/wiki/Samuel_Smiles "Samuel Smiles") by the
[protonolysis](/wiki/Protonolysis "Protonolysis") of [magnesium
silicides](/wiki/Magnesium_silicide "Magnesium silicide"). Further
investigation had to wait until 1916 because of the great reactivity and
thermal instability of the silanes; it was then that [Alfred
Stock](/wiki/Alfred_Stock "Alfred Stock") began the study of silicon hydrides
in earnest with new greaseless vacuum techniques, as they were found as
contaminants of his focus, the [boron hydrides](/wiki/Borane "Borane"). The
names _silanes_ and _boranes_ are due to him, based on analogy with the
[alkanes](/wiki/Alkane "Alkane").[26][40][41] Moissan and Smiles' method of
preparation of silanes and silane derivatives via protonolysis of metal
silicides is still used, although the yield is lowered by the hydrolysis of
the products that occurs simultaneously, and thus the preferred route today is
to treat substituted silanes with hydride reducing agents such as [lithium
aluminium hydride](/wiki/Lithium_aluminium_hydride "Lithium aluminium
hydride") in etheric solutions at low temperatures. Direct reaction of HX or
RX with silicon, possibly with a catalyst such as copper, is also a viable
method to produce substituted silanes.[26]

The silanes comprise a [homologous series](/wiki/Homologous_series "Homologous
series") of silicon hydrides with the general formula Si _n_ H2 _n_ \+ 2. They
are all strong [reducing agents](/wiki/Reducing_agent "Reducing agent").
Unbranched and branched trains are known up to _n_ = 8, and the cycles Si5H10
and Si6H12 are also known. The first two, silane and disilane, are colourless
gases; the heavier members of the series are volatile liquids. All silanes are
very reactive and catch fire or explode spontaneously in air. They become less
thermally stable with room temperature, so that only silane is indefinitely
stable at room temperature, although disilane does not decompose very quickly
(only 2.5% of a sample decomposes after eight months have passed).[26] They
decompose to form polymeric [polysilicon hydride](/wiki/Polysilicon_hydride
"Polysilicon hydride") and hydrogen gas.[42][43] As expected from the
difference in atomic weight, the silanes are less volatile than the
corresponding alkanes and boranes, but more volatile than the corresponding
germanes. They are much more reactive than the corresponding alkanes, because
the larger radius of silicon compared to carbon facilitates [nucleophilic
attack](/wiki/Nucleophile "Nucleophile") at the silicon, the greater polarity
of the Si–H bond compared to the C–H bond, and the ability of silicon to
expand its octet and hence form adducts and lower the reaction's [activation
energy](/wiki/Activation_energy "Activation energy").[26]

Silane [pyrolysis](/wiki/Pyrolysis "Pyrolysis") gives polymeric species and
finally elemental silicon and hydrogen; indeed ultrapure silicon is
commercially produced by the pyrolysis of silane. While the thermal
decomposition of alkanes starts by the breaking of a C–H or C–C bond and the
formation of radical intermediates, polysilanes decompose by eliminating
[silenes](/wiki/Silene "Silene") :SiH2 or :SiHR, as the activation energy of
this process (~210 kJ/mol) is much less than the Si–Si and Si–H bond energies.
While pure silanes do not react with pure water or dilute acids, traces of
alkali catalyse immediate hydrolysis to hydrated silicon dioxide. If the
reaction is carried out in [methanol](/wiki/Methanol "Methanol"), controlled
solvolysis results in the products SiH2(OMe)2, SiH(OMe)3, and Si(OMe)4. The
Si–H bond also adds to [alkenes](/wiki/Alkene "Alkene"), a reaction which
proceeds slowly and speeds up with increasing substitution of the silane
involved. At 450 °C, silane participates in an [addition
reaction](/wiki/Addition_reaction "Addition reaction") with
[acetone](/wiki/Acetone "Acetone"), as well as a [ring-opening
reaction](/wiki/Ring-opening_reaction "Ring-opening reaction") with [ethylene
oxide](/wiki/Ethylene_oxide "Ethylene oxide"). Direct reaction of the silanes
with chlorine or bromine results in explosions at room temperature, but the
reaction of silane with bromine at −80 °C is controlled and yields bromosilane
and dibromosilane. The monohalosilanes may be formed by reacting silane with
the appropriate [hydrogen halide](/wiki/Hydrogen_halide "Hydrogen halide")
with an Al2X6 catalyst, or by reacting silane with a solid
[silver](/wiki/Silver "Silver") halide in a heated flow reactor:[26]

    SiH4 \+ 2 AgCl 260 °C→ SiH3Cl + HCl + 2 Ag

Among the derivatives of silane, [iodosilane](/wiki/Iodosilane "Iodosilane")
(SiH3I) and [potassium
silanide](/w/index.php?title=Potassium_silanide&action=edit&redlink=1
"Potassium silanide \(page does not exist\)") (KSiH3) are very useful
synthetic intermediates in the production of more complicated silicon-
containing compounds: the latter is a colourless crystalline ionic solid
containing K+ cations and SiH−  
3 anions in the [NaCl](/wiki/Sodium_chloride "Sodium chloride") structure, and
is made by the reduction of silane by [potassium](/wiki/Potassium "Potassium")
metal.[44] Additionally, the reactive hypervalent species SiH−  
5 is also known.[26] With suitable organic substituents it is possible to
produce stable polysilanes: they have surprisingly high electric
conductivities, arising from [sigma](/wiki/Sigma_bond "Sigma bond")
delocalisation of the electrons in the chain.[45]

### Halides

Silicon and [silicon carbide](/wiki/Silicon_carbide "Silicon carbide") readily
react with all four stable halogens, forming the colourless, reactive and
volatile silicon tetrahalides.[46] [Silicon
tetrafluoride](/wiki/Silicon_tetrafluoride "Silicon tetrafluoride") may also
be made by fluorinating the other silicon halides, and is produced by the
attack of [hydrofluoric acid](/wiki/Hydrofluoric_acid "Hydrofluoric acid") on
glass.[47] Heating two different tetrahalides together also produce a random
mixture of mixed halides, which may also be produced by halogen exchange
reactions. The melting and boiling points of these species usually rise with
increasing atomic weight, though there are many exceptions: for example, the
melting and boiling points drop as one passes from SiFBr3 through SiFClBr2 to
SiFCl2Br. The shift from the hypoelectronic elements in group 13 and earlier
to the group 14 elements is illustrated by the change from an infinite ionic
structure in [aluminium fluoride](/wiki/Aluminium_fluoride "Aluminium
fluoride") to a lattice of simple covalent silicon tetrafluoride molecules, as
dictated by the lower electronegativity of aluminium than silicon, the
stoichiometry (the +4 oxidation state being too high for true ionicity), and
the smaller size of the silicon atom compared to the aluminium atom.[46]
[Silicon tetrachloride](/wiki/Silicon_tetrachloride "Silicon tetrachloride")
is manufactured on a huge scale as a precursor to the production of pure
silicon, silicon dioxide, and some silicon [esters](/wiki/Ester "Ester").[46]
The silicon tetrahalides hydrolyse readily in water, unlike the carbon
tetrahalides, again because of the larger size of the silicon atom rendering
it more open to nucleophilic attack and the ability of the silicon atom to
expand its octet which carbon lacks.[47] The reaction of silicon fluoride with
excess [hydrofluoric acid](/wiki/Hydrofluoric_acid "Hydrofluoric acid")
produces the octahedral [hexafluorosilicate](/wiki/Hexafluorosilicic_acid
"Hexafluorosilicic acid") anion SiF2−  
6.[47]

Analogous to the silanes, halopolysilanes Si _n_ X2 _n_ \+ 2 are also known.
While catenation in carbon compounds is maximised in the hydrogen compounds
rather than the halides, the opposite is true for silicon, so that the
halopolysilanes are known up to at least Si14F30, Si6Cl14, and Si4Br10. A
suggested explanation for this phenomenon is the compensation for the electron
loss of silicon to the more electronegative halogen atoms by [pi
backbonding](/wiki/Pi_backbonding "Pi backbonding") from the filled pπ
orbitals on the halogen atoms to the empty dπ orbitals on silicon: this is
similar to the situation of [carbon monoxide](/wiki/Carbon_monoxide "Carbon
monoxide") in [metal carbonyl complexes](/wiki/Metal_carbonyl_complex "Metal
carbonyl complex") and explains their stability. These halopolysilanes may be
produced by [comproportionation](/wiki/Comproportionation
"Comproportionation") of silicon tetrahalides with elemental silicon, or by
condensation of lighter halopolysilanes
([trimethylammonium](/wiki/Trimethylammonium "Trimethylammonium") being a
useful catalyst for this reaction).[46]

### Silica

[Silicon dioxide](/wiki/Silicon_dioxide "Silicon dioxide") (SiO2), also known
as silica, is one of the most well-studied compounds, second only to
[water](/wiki/Properties_of_water "Properties of water"). Twelve different
crystal modifications of silica are known, the most common being
α-[quartz](/wiki/Quartz "Quartz"), a major constituent of many rocks such as
[granite](/wiki/Granite "Granite") and [sandstone](/wiki/Sandstone
"Sandstone"). It is also known to occur pure as [rock
crystal](/wiki/Rock_crystal "Rock crystal"); impure forms are known as [rose
quartz](/wiki/Rose_quartz "Rose quartz"), [smoky quartz](/wiki/Smoky_quartz
"Smoky quartz"), [morion](/wiki/Morion_\(mineral\) "Morion \(mineral\)"),
[amethyst](/wiki/Amethyst "Amethyst"), and [citrine](/wiki/Citrine "Citrine").
Some poorly crystalline forms of quartz are also known, such as
[chalcedony](/wiki/Chalcedony "Chalcedony"), [chrysoprase](/wiki/Chrysoprase
"Chrysoprase"), [carnelian](/wiki/Carnelian "Carnelian"), [agate](/wiki/Agate
"Agate"), [onyx](/wiki/Onyx "Onyx"), [jasper](/wiki/Jasper "Jasper"),
[heliotrope](/wiki/Heliotrope_\(mineral\) "Heliotrope \(mineral\)"), and
[flint](/wiki/Flint "Flint"). Other modifications of silicon dioxide are known
in some other minerals such as [tridymite](/wiki/Tridymite "Tridymite") and
[cristobalite](/wiki/Cristobalite "Cristobalite"), as well as the much less
common [coesite](/wiki/Coesite "Coesite") and [stishovite](/wiki/Stishovite
"Stishovite"). Biologically generated forms are also known as
[kieselguhr](/wiki/Kieselguhr "Kieselguhr") and [diatomaceous
earth](/wiki/Diatomaceous_earth "Diatomaceous earth").
[Vitreous](/wiki/Vitrification "Vitrification") silicon dioxide is known as
[tectites](/wiki/Tectite "Tectite"), and [obsidian](/wiki/Obsidian
"Obsidian"), and rarely as [lechatelierite](/wiki/Lechatelierite
"Lechatelierite"). Some synthetic forms are known as [keatite](/wiki/Keatite
"Keatite") and [W-silica](/w/index.php?title=W-silica&action=edit&redlink=1
"W-silica \(page does not exist\)"). [Opals](/wiki/Opal "Opal") are composed
of complicated crystalline aggregates of partially hydrated silicon
dioxide.[48]

Lechatelierite

Most crystalline forms of silica are made of infinite arrangements of {SiO4}
tetrahedra connected at their corners, with each oxygen atom linked to two
silicon atoms. In the thermodynamically stable room-temperature form,
α-quartz, these tetrahedra are linked in intertwined helical chains with two
different Si–O distances (159.7 and 161.7 pm) with a Si–O–Si angle of 144°.
These helices can be either left- or right-handed, so that individual α-quartz
crystals are optically active. At 537 °C, this transforms quickly and
reversibly into the similar β-quartz, with a change of the Si–O–Si angle to
155° but a retention of handedness. Further heating to 867 °C results in
another reversible phase transition to β-tridymite, in which some Si–O bonds
are broken to allow for the arrangement of the {SiO4} tetrahedra into a more
open and less dense hexagonal structure. This transition is slow and hence
tridymite occurs as a metastable mineral even below this transition
temperature; when cooled to about 120 °C it quickly and reversibly transforms
by slight displacements of individual silicon and oxygen atoms to α-tridymite,
similarly to the transition from α-quartz to β-quartz. β-tridymite slowly
transforms to cubic β-cristobalite at about 1470 °C, which once again exists
metastably below this transition temperature and transforms at 200–280 °C to
α-cristobalite via small atomic displacements. β-cristobalite melts at 1713
°C; the freezing of silica from themelt is quite slow and
[vitrification](/wiki/Vitrification "Vitrification"), or the formation of a
[glass](/wiki/Glass "Glass"), is likely to occur instead. In vitreous silica,
the {SiO4} tetrahedra remain corner-connected, but the symmetry and
periodicity of the crystalline forms are lost. Because of the slow conversions
between these three forms, it is possible upon rapid heating to melt β-quartz
(1550 °C) or β-tridymite (1703 °C). Silica boils at approximately 2800 °C.
Other high-pressure forms of silica are known, such as coesite and stishovite:
these are known in nature, formed under the shock pressure of a meteorite
impact and then rapidly quenched to preserve the crystal structure. Similar
melting and cooling of silica occurs following [lightning](/wiki/Lightning
"Lightning") strikes, forming glassy [lechatelierite](/wiki/Lechatelierite
"Lechatelierite"). W-silica is an unstable low-density form involving {SiO4}
tetrahedra sharing opposite edges instead of corners, forming parallel chains
similarly to [silicon disulfide](/wiki/Silicon_disulfide "Silicon disulfide")
(SiS2) and [silicon
diselenide](/w/index.php?title=Silicon_diselenide&action=edit&redlink=1
"Silicon diselenide \(page does not exist\)") (SiSe2): it quickly returns to
forming amorphous silica with heat or traces of water.[48]

Condensed polysilicic acid

Silica is rather inert chemically. It is not attacked by any acids other than
hydrofluoric acid. However, it slowly dissolves in hot concentrated alkalis,
and does so rather quickly in fused metal hydroxides or carbonates to give
metal silicates. Among the elements, it is attacked only by fluorine at room
temperature to form silicon tetrafluoride: hydrogen and carbon also react, but
require temperatures over 1000 °C to do so. Silica nevertheless reacts with
many metal and [metalloid](/wiki/Metalloid "Metalloid") oxides to form a wide
variety of compounds important in the glass and ceramic industries above all,
but also have many other uses: for example, [sodium
silicate](/wiki/Sodium_silicate "Sodium silicate") is often used in detergents
due to its [buffering](/wiki/Buffer_\(chemistry\) "Buffer \(chemistry\)"),
[saponifying](/wiki/Saponification "Saponification"), and
[emulsifying](/wiki/Emulsification "Emulsification") properties.[48]

### Silicic acids

Adding water to silica drops its melting point by around 800 °C due to the
breaking of the structure by replacing Si–O–Si linkages with terminating Si–OH
groups. Increasing water concentration results in the formation of hydrated
[silica gels](/wiki/Silica_gel "Silica gel") and [colloidal](/wiki/Colloid
"Colloid") silica dispersions. Many hydrates and [silicic
acids](/wiki/Silicic_acid "Silicic acid") exist in the most dilute of aqueous
solutions, but these are rather insoluble and quickly precipitate and condense
and cross-link to form various polysilicic acids of variable combinations
following the formula [SiO _x_(OH)4−2 _x_]_n_ , similar to the behaviour of
[boron](/wiki/Boron "Boron"), [aluminium](/wiki/Aluminium "Aluminium"), and
[iron](/wiki/Iron "Iron"), among other elements. Hence, although some simple
silicic acids have been identified in dilute solutions, such as [orthosilicic
acid](/wiki/Orthosilicic_acid "Orthosilicic acid") Si(OH)4 and [metasilicic
acid](/w/index.php?title=Metasilicic_acid&action=edit&redlink=1 "Metasilicic
acid \(page does not exist\)") SiO(OH)2, none of these are likely to exist in
the solid state.[48]

About 95% of the Earth's [crustal](/wiki/Crust_\(geology\) "Crust

[aluminosilicate](/wiki/Aluminosilicate "Aluminosilicate") minerals, as

elements in the crust (in that order).[49] Measured by mass, silicon makes up

silicon crystals are very rarely found in nature, but notable exceptions are

[Kudriavy](/wiki/Medvezhya "Medvezhya") volcano on the island of
[Iturup](/wiki/Iturup "Iturup"), one of the [Kuril
Islands](/wiki/Kuril_Islands "Kuril Islands").[51][52]

Silicate and aluminosilicate minerals have many different structures and
varying stoichiometry, but they may be classified following some general
principles. Tetrahedral {SiO4} units are common to almost all these compounds,
either as discrete structures, or combined into larger units by the sharing of
corner oxygen atoms. These may be divided into _neso_ -silicates (discrete
{SiO4} units) sharing no oxygen atoms, _soro_ -silicates (discrete {Si2O7}
units) sharing one, _cyclo_ -silicates (closed ring structures) and _ino_
-silicates (continuous chain or ribbon structures) both sharing two, _phyllo_
-silicates (continuous sheets) sharing three, and _tecto_ -silicates
(continuous three-dimensional frameworks) sharing four. The lattice of oxygen
atoms that results is usually close-packed or close to it, with the charge
being balanced by other cations in various different polyhedral sites
according to size.[49]

The [orthosilicates](/wiki/Orthosilicate "Orthosilicate") MII

([phenacite](/wiki/Phenacite "Phenacite")) is rather unusual as both BeII and
SiIV occupy tetrahedral four-coordinated sites; the other divalent cations
instead occupy six-coordinated octahedral sites and often isomorphously
replace each other as in [olivine](/wiki/Olivine "Olivine"), (Mg,Fe,Mn)2SiO4.
[Zircon](/wiki/Zircon "Zircon"), ZrSiO4, demands eight-coordination of the
ZrIV cations due to stoichiometry and because of their larger ionic radius (84
pm). Also significant are the [garnets](/wiki/Garnet "Garnet"), [MII

is not always present: for example, it is not found in Ca2SiO4, which mixes
six- and eight-coordinate sites for CaII. _Soro_ -silicates, involving
discrete double or triple tetrahedral units, are quite rare: metasilicates
involving cyclic "[(SiO3)_n_]2 _n_ −" units of corner-abutting tetrahedra
forming a polygonal ring are also known.[49]

Chain metasilicates, {SiO2−  
3}  
∞, form by the corner-sharing of an indefinite chain of linked {SiO4}
tetrahedra. Many differences arise due to the differing repeat distances of
conformation across the line of tetrahedra. A repeat distance of two is most
common, as in most [pyroxene](/wiki/Pyroxene "Pyroxene") minerals, but repeat
distances of one, three, four, five, six, seven, nine, and twelve are also
known. These chains can then link across each other to form double chains and
ribbons, as in the [asbestos](/wiki/Asbestos "Asbestos") minerals, involving
repeated chains of cyclic tetrahedron rings.[49]

Layer silicates, such as the clay minerals and the [micas](/wiki/Mica "Mica"),
are very common, and are often formed by horizontal cross-linking of
metasilicate chains or planar condensation of smaller units. An example is
[kaolinite](/wiki/Kaolinite "Kaolinite") [Al2(OH)4Si2O5]; in many of these
minerals cation and anion replacement is common, so that for example
tetrahedral SiIV may be replaced by AlIII, octahedral AlIII by MgII, and OH−
by F−. Three-dimensional framework aluminosilicates are structurally very
complex; they may be conceived of as starting from the SiO2 structure, but
having replaced up to one-half of the SiIV atoms with AlIII they require more
cations to be included in the structure to balance charge. Examples include
[feldspars](/wiki/Feldspar "Feldspar") (the most abundant minerals on the
Earth), [zeolites](/wiki/Zeolite "Zeolite"), and
[ultramarines](/wiki/Ultramarine "Ultramarine"). Many feldspars can be thought
of as forming part of the ternary system NaAlSi3O8–KAlSi3O8–CaAl2Si2O8. Their
lattice is destroyed by high pressure prompting AlIII to undergo six-
coordination rather than four-coordination, and this reaction destroying
feldspars may be a reason for the [Mohorovičić
discontinuity](/wiki/Mohorovi%C4%8Di%C4%87_discontinuity "Mohorovičić
discontinuity"), which would imply that the crust and mantle have the same
chemical composition but different lattices, although this is not a
universally held view. Zeolites have many polyhedral cavities in their
frameworks ([truncated cuboctahedra](/wiki/Truncated_cuboctahedron "Truncated
cuboctahedron") being most common, but other polyhedra are also known as
zeolite cavities), allowing them to include loosely bound molecules such as
water in their structure. Ultramarines alternate silicon and aluminium atoms
and include a variety of other anions such as Cl−, SO2−  
4, and S2−  
2, but are otherwise similar to the feldspars.[49]

### Other inorganic compounds

[Silicon disulfide](/wiki/Silicon_disulfide "Silicon disulfide") (SiS2) is
formed by burning silicon in gaseous sulfur at 100 °C; sublimation of the
resulting compound in nitrogen results in white, flexible long fibres
reminiscent of [asbestos](/wiki/Asbestos "Asbestos") with a structure similar
to W-silica. This melts at 1090 °C and sublimes at 1250 °C; at high
temperature and pressure this transforms to a crystal structure analogous to
cristobalite. However, SiS2 lacks the variety of structures of SiO2, and
quickly hydrolyses to silica and [hydrogen sulfide](/wiki/Hydrogen_sulfide
"Hydrogen sulfide"). It is also ammonoloysed quickly and completely by liquid
[ammonia](/wiki/Ammonia "Ammonia") as follows to form an [imide](/wiki/Imide
"Imide"):[53]

    SiS2 \+ 4 NH3 → Si(NH)2 \+ 2 NH4SH

It reacts with the sulfides of sodium, magnesium, aluminium, and iron to form
metal [thiosilicates](/w/index.php?title=Thiosilicate&action=edit&redlink=1
"Thiosilicate \(page does not exist\)"): reaction with [ethanol](/wiki/Ethanol
"Ethanol") results in
[ethylsilicate](/w/index.php?title=Ethylsilicate&action=edit&redlink=1
"Ethylsilicate \(page does not exist\)") Si(OEt)4 and hydrogen sulfide.
Ethylsilicate is useful as its controlled hydrolysis produces adhesive or
film-like forms of silica. Reacting hydrogen sulfide with silicon tetrahalides
yields silicon thiohalides such as S(SiCl)3, cyclic Cl2Si(μ-S)2SiCl2, and
crystalline (SiSCl2)4. Despite the [double bond rule](/wiki/Double_bond_rule
"Double bond rule"), stable organosilanethiones RR'Si=S have been made thanks
to the stabilising mechanism of intermolecular coordination via an
[amine](/wiki/Amine "Amine") group.[53]

[Silicon nitride](/wiki/Silicon_nitride "Silicon nitride"), Si3N4, can be
formed by directly reacting silicon with nitrogen above 1300 °C, but a more
economical means of production is by heating silica and coke in a stream of
nitrogen and hydrogen gas at 1500 °C. It would make a promising
[ceramic](/wiki/Ceramic "Ceramic") if not for the difficulty of working with
and sintering it: it is chemically near-totally inert, and even above 1000 °C
it keeps its strength, shape, and continues to be resistant to wear and
corrosion. It is very hard (9 on the [Mohs hardness
scale](/wiki/Mohs_hardness_scale "Mohs hardness scale")), dissociates only at
1900 °C at 1 atm, and is quite dense (density 3.185 g/cm3), because of its
compact structure similar to that of phenacite (Be2SiO4). A similar refractory
material is Si2N2O, formed by heating silicon and silica at 1450 °C in an
argon stream containing 5% nitrogen gas, involving 4-coordinate silicon and
3-coordinate nitrogen alternating in puckered hexagonal tilings interlinked by
non-linear Si–O–Si linkages to each other.[53]

Reacting silyl halides with ammonia or alkylammonia derivatives in the gaseous
phase or in ethanolic solution produces various volatile silylamides, which
are silicon analogues of the [amines](/wiki/Amine "Amine"):[53]

    3 SiH3Cl + 4 NH3 → N(SiH3)3 \+ 3 NH4Cl
    SiH3Br + 2 Me2NH → SiH3NMe2 \+ Me2NH2Br
    4 SiH3I + 5 N2H4 → (SiH3)2NN(SiH3)2 \+ 4 N2H5I

Many such compounds have been prepared, the only known restriction being that
the nitrogen is always tertiary, and species containing the SiH–NH group are
unstable at room temperature. The stoichiometry around the nitrogen atom in
compounds such as N(SiH3)3is planar, which has been attributed to a pπ–dπ
interaction between a lone pair on nitrogen and an empty dπ orbital on
silicon. Similarly, trisilylamines are weaker as ligands than their carbon
analogues, the tertiary [amines](/wiki/Amine "Amine"), although substitution
of some SiH3 groups by CH3 groups mitigates this weakness. Thus, for example,
N(SiH3)3 does not form an [adduct](/wiki/Adduct "Adduct") with
[BH3](/wiki/Borane "Borane") at all, while MeN(SiH3)2 and Me2NSiH3 form
adducts at low temperatures that decompose upon warming. Some silicon
analogues of [imines](/wiki/Imine "Imine"), with a Si=N double bond, are
known: the first found was Bu _t_ 2Si=N–SiBu _t_ 3, which was discovered in
1986.[53]

[Silicon carbide](/wiki/Silicon_carbide "Silicon carbide") (SiC) was first
made by [Edward Goodrich Acheson](/wiki/Edward_Goodrich_Acheson "Edward
Goodrich Acheson") in 1891, who named it carborundum to reference its
intermediate hardness and abrasive power between [diamond](/wiki/Diamond
"Diamond") (an allotrope of carbon) and [corundum](/wiki/Corundum "Corundum")
([aluminium oxide](/wiki/Aluminium_oxide "Aluminium oxide")). He soon founded
a company to manufacture it, and today about one million tonnes are produced
each year.[54] Silicon carbide exists in about 250 crystalline forms.[55] The
polymorphism of SiC is characterized by a large family of similar crystalline
structures called polytypes. They are variations of the same chemical compound
that are identical in two dimensions and differ in the third. Thus, they can
be viewed as layers stacked in a certain sequence.[56] It is made industrially
by reduction of quartz sand with excess coke or anthracite at 2000–2500 °C in
an electric furnace:[54]

    SiO2 \+ 2 C → Si + 2 CO
    Si + C → SiC

It is the most thermally stable binary silicon compound, only decomposing
through loss of silicon starting from around 2700 °C. It is resistant to most
aqueous acids, [phosphoric acid](/wiki/Phosphoric_acid "Phosphoric acid")
being an exception. It forms a protective layer of [silicon
dioxide](/wiki/Silicon_dioxide "Silicon dioxide") on the surface and hence
only oxidises appreciably in air above 1000 °C; removal of this layer by
molten hydroxides or carbonates leads to quick oxidation. Silicon carbide is
rapidly attacked by chlorine gas, which forms SiCl4 and carbon at 100 °C and
SiCl4 and [CCl4](/wiki/Carbon_tetrachloride "Carbon tetrachloride") at 1000
°C. It is mostly used as an abrasive and a refractory materia, as it is
chemically stable and very strong, and it fractures to form a very sharp
cutting edge. It is also useful as an intrinsic semiconductor, as well as an
extrinsic semiconductor upon being doped.[54] In its diamond-like behaviour it
serves as an illustration of the chemical similarity between carbon and
silicon.[57]

### Organosilicon compounds

Main article: [Organosilicon](/wiki/Organosilicon "Organosilicon")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c9/HydrosilylationTriphenylsilylhydride.png/400px-
HydrosilylationTriphenylsilylhydride.png)](/wiki/File:HydrosilylationTriphenylsilylhydride.png)

[](/wiki/File:HydrosilylationTriphenylsilylhydride.png "Enlarge")

A hydrosilylation reaction, in which Si–H is added to an unsaturated substrate

Because the Si–C bond is close in strength to the C–C bond, organosilicon
compounds tend to be markedly thermally and chemically stable. For example,
[tetraphenylsilane](/w/index.php?title=Tetraphenylsilane&action=edit&redlink=1
"Tetraphenylsilane \(page does not exist\)") (SiPh4) may be distilled in air
even at its boiling point of 428 °C, and so can its substituted derivatives
Ph3SiCl and Ph2SiCl2, which boil at 378 °C and 305 °C respectively.
Furthermore, since carbon and silicon are chemical congeners, organosilicon
chemistry shows some significant similarities with carbon chemistry, for
example in the propensity of such compounds for catenation and forming
multiple bonds.[57] However, significant differences also arise: since silicon
is more electropositive than carbon, bonds to more electronegative elements
are generally stronger with silicon than with carbon, and vice versa. Thus the
Si–F bond is significantly stronger than even the [C–F
bond](/wiki/Carbon%E2%80%93fluorine_bond "Carbon–fluorine bond") and is one of
the strongest single bonds, while the Si–H bond is much weaker than the C–H
bond and is readily broken. Furthermore, the ability of silicon to expand its
octet is not shared by carbon, and hence some organosilicon reactions have no
organic analogues. For example, nucleophilic attack on silicon does not
proceed by the [SN2](/wiki/SN2_reaction "SN2 reaction") or
[SN1](/wiki/SN1_reaction "SN1 reaction") processes, but instead goes through a
negatively charged true pentacoordinate intermediate and appears like a
substitution at a hindered tertiary atom. This works for silicon, unlike for
carbon, because the long Si–C bonds reduce the steric hindrance and the
d-orbital of silicon is geometrically unconstrained for nucleophilic attack,
unlike for example a C–O σ* antibonding orbital. Nevertheless, despite these
differences, the mechanism is still often called "SN2 at silicon" for
simplicity.[58]

One of the most useful silicon-containing groups is
[trimethylsilyl](/wiki/Trimethylsilyl "Trimethylsilyl"), Me3Si–. The Si–C bond
connecting it to the rest of the molecule is reasonably strong, allowing it to
remain while the rest of the molecule undergoes reactions, but is not so
strong that it cannot be removed specifically when needed, for example by the
[fluoride](/wiki/Fluoride "Fluoride") ion, which is a very weak nucleophile
for carbon compounds but a very strong one for organosilicon compounds. It may
be compared to acidic [protons](/wiki/Proton "Proton"); while trisilylmethyl
is removed by hard nucleophiles instead of bases, both removals usually
promote elimination. As a general rule, while saturated carbon is best
attacked by nucleophiles that are neutral compounds, those based on nonmetals
far down on the periodic table (e.g. sulfur, [selenium](/wiki/Selenium
"Selenium"), or [iodine](/wiki/Iodine "Iodine")), or even both, silicon is
best attacked by charged nucleophiles, particularly those involving such
highly electronegative nonmetals as oxygen, fluorine, or chlorine. For
example, enolates react at the carbon in [haloalkanes](/wiki/Haloalkane
"Haloalkane"), but at the oxygen in [silyl](/wiki/Silyl "Silyl") chlorides;
and when trimethylsilyl is removed from an organic molecule using hydroxide as
a nucleophile, the product of the reaction is not the silanol as one would
expect from using carbon chemistry as an analogy, because the siloxide is
strongly nucleophilic and attacks the original molecule to yield the [silyl
ether](/wiki/Silyl_ether "Silyl ether")
[hexamethyldisiloxane](/wiki/Hexamethyldisiloxane "Hexamethyldisiloxane"),
(Me3Si)2O. Conversely, while the SN2 reaction is mostly unaffected by the
presence of a partial positive charge (δ+) at the carbon, the analogous "SN2"
reaction at silicon is so affected. Thus, for example, the silyl
[triflates](/wiki/Triflate "Triflate") are so electrophilic that they react
108 to 109 times faster than silyl chlorides with oxygen-containing
nucleophiles. [Trimethylsilyl triflate](/wiki/Trimethylsilyl_triflate
"Trimethylsilyl triflate") is in particular a very good [Lewis
acid](/wiki/Lewis_acid "Lewis acid") and is used to convert
[carbonyl](/wiki/Carbonyl "Carbonyl") compounds to [acetals](/wiki/Acetal
"Acetal") and [silyl enol ethers](/wiki/Silyl_enol_ether "Silyl enol ether"),
reacting them together analogously to the [aldol
reaction](/wiki/Aldol_reaction "Aldol reaction").[58]

Si–C bonds are commonly formed in three ways. In the laboratory, preparation
is often carried out in small quantities by reacting tetrachlorosilane with
[organolithium](/wiki/Organolithium "Organolithium"),
[Grignard](/wiki/Grignard_reagent "Grignard reagent"), or
[organoaluminium](/wiki/Organoaluminium "Organoaluminium") reagents, or by
catalytic addition of Si–H across C=C double bonds. The second route has the
drawback of not being applicable to the most important silanes, the methyl and
phenyl silanes. Organosilanes are made industrially by directly reacting alkyl
or aryl halides with silicon with 10% by weight metallic [copper](/wiki/Copper
"Copper") as a catalyst. Standard organic reactions suffice to produce many
derivatives; the resulting organosilanes are often significantly more reactive
than their carbon congeners, readily undergoing hydrolysis, ammonolysis,
alcoholysis, and condensation to form cyclic oligomers or linear polymers.[57]

Main article: [Silicone](/wiki/Silicone "Silicone")
