The word "silicone" was first used by [Frederick
Kipping](/wiki/Frederick_Kipping "Frederick Kipping") in 1901. He invented the
word to illustrate the similarity of chemical formulae between Ph2SiO and
[benzophenone](/wiki/Benzophenone "Benzophenone"), Ph2CO, although he also
stressed the lack of chemical resemblance due to the polymeric structure of
Ph2SiO, which is not shared by Ph2CO.[57]

Silicones may be considered analogous to mineral silicates, in which the
methyl groups of the silicones correspond to the
[isoelectronic](/wiki/Isoelectronic "Isoelectronic") O− of the silicates.[57]
They are quite stable to extreme temperatures, oxidation, and water, and have
useful dielectric, antistick, and antifoam properties. Furthermore, they are
resistant over long periods of time to ultraviolet radiation and weathering,
and are inert physiologically. They are fairly unreactive, but do react with
concentrated solutions bearing the hydroxide ion and fluorinating agents, and
occasionally can be even used as mild reagents for selective syntheses. For
example, (Me3Si)2O is valuable for the preparation of derivatives of
[molybdenum](/wiki/Molybdenum "Molybdenum") and [tungsten](/wiki/Tungsten
"Tungsten") oxyhalides, converting a [tungsten
hexachloride](/wiki/Tungsten_hexachloride "Tungsten hexachloride") suspension
in [dichloroethane](/wiki/Dichloroethane "Dichloroethane") solution
quantitatively to WOCl4 in under an hour at room temperature, and then to
yellow WO2Cl2 at 100 °C in light petroleum at a yield of 95% overnight.[57]

## Occurrence

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fb/Olivine-
gem7-10a.jpg/220px-Olivine-gem7-10a.jpg)](/wiki/File:Olivine-gem7-10a.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Olivine-gem7-10a.jpg "Enlarge")

Olivine

In the universe, silicon is the seventh most abundant element, coming after
[hydrogen](/wiki/Hydrogen "Hydrogen"), [helium](/wiki/Helium "Helium"),
[carbon](/wiki/Carbon "Carbon"), [nitrogen](/wiki/Nitrogen "Nitrogen"),
[oxygen](/wiki/Oxygen "Oxygen"), and [neon](/wiki/Neon "Neon"). These
abundances are not replicated well on Earth due to substantial separation of
the elements taking place during the formation of the [Solar
System](/wiki/Solar_System "Solar System"). Silicon makes up 27.2% of the
Earth's crust by weight, second only to oxygen at 45.5%, with which it is
always associated in nature. Further fractionation took place in the formation
of the Earth by [planetary differentiation](/wiki/Planetary_differentiation
"Planetary differentiation"): [Earth's core](/wiki/Earth%27s_core "Earth's
core"), which makes up 31.5% of the mass of the Earth, has approximate
composition Fe25Ni2Co0.1S3; the [mantle](/wiki/Mantle_\(geology\) "Mantle
\(geology\)") makes up 68.1% of the Earth's mass and is composed mostly of
denser oxides and silicates, an example being [olivine](/wiki/Olivine
"Olivine"), (Mg,Fe)2SiO4; while the lighter siliceous minerals rise to the
surface and form the crust, making up 0.4% of the Earth's mass.[59]

The crystallisation of [igneous rocks](/wiki/Igneous_rock "Igneous rock") from
magma depends on a number of factors; among them are the chemical composition
of the magma, the cooling rate, and some properties of the individual minerals
to be formed, such as [lattice energy](/wiki/Lattice_energy "Lattice energy"),
melting point, and complexity of their crystal structure. As magma is cooled,
[olivine](/wiki/Olivine "Olivine") appears first, followed by
[pyroxene](/wiki/Pyroxene "Pyroxene"), [amphibole](/wiki/Amphibole
"Amphibole"), [biotite](/wiki/Biotite "Biotite") mica, [orthoclase
feldspar](/wiki/Orthoclase_feldspar "Orthoclase feldspar"), [muscovite
mica](/wiki/Muscovite_mica "Muscovite mica"), [quartz](/wiki/Quartz "Quartz"),
[zeolites](/wiki/Zeolite "Zeolite"), and finally hydrothermal minerals. This
sequence shows a trend towards increasingly complex silicate units with
cooling, and the introduction of [hydroxide](/wiki/Hydroxide "Hydroxide") and
[fluoride](/wiki/Fluoride "Fluoride") anions in addition to oxides. Many
metals can substitute for silicon. After these igneous rocks undergo
[weathering](/wiki/Weathering "Weathering"), transport, and deposition,
[sedimentary rocks](/wiki/Sedimentary_rock "Sedimentary rock") like clay,
shale, and sandstone are formed. [Metamorphism](/wiki/Metamorphism
"Metamorphism") also can occur at high temperatures and pressures, creating an
even vaster variety of minerals.[59]

## Production

Silicon of 96–99% purity is made by reducing [quartzite](/wiki/Quartzite
"Quartzite") or sand with highly pure [coke](/wiki/Coke_\(fuel\) "Coke
\(fuel\)"). The reduction is carried out in an [electric arc
furnace](/wiki/Electric_arc_furnace "Electric arc furnace"), with an excess of
SiO2 used to stop silicon carbide from accumulating:[33]

    SiO2 \+ 2 C → Si + 2 CO
    2 SiC + SiO2 → 3 Si + 2 CO

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/51/Ferrosilicon.JPG/200px-
Ferrosilicon.JPG)](/wiki/File:Ferrosilicon.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Ferrosilicon.JPG "Enlarge")

Ferrosilicon alloy

This reaction, known as carbothermal reduction of silicon dioxide, is usually
conducted in the presence of scrap iron with low amounts of
[phosphorus](/wiki/Phosphorus "Phosphorus") and [sulfur](/wiki/Sulfur
"Sulfur"), produing [ferrosilicon](/wiki/Ferrosilicon "Ferrosilicon").[33]
Ferrosilicon, an iron-silicon alloy that contains varying ratios of elemental
silicon and iron, accounts for about 80% of the world's production of
elemental silicon, with China, the leading supplier of elemental silicon,
providing 4.6 million [tonnes](/wiki/Tonne "Tonne") (or 2/3 of the world
output) of silicon, most of which is in the form of ferrosilicon. It is
followed by Russia (610,000 t), Norway (330,000 t), Brazil (240,000 t) and the
United States (170,000 t).[60] Ferrosilicon is primarily used by the iron and
steel industry (see below) with primary use as alloying addition in iron or
steel and for de-oxidation of steel in integrated steel plants.[33] Another
sometimes used reaction is aluminothermal reduction of silicon dioxide, as
follows:[61]

    3 SiO2 \+ 4 Al → 3 Si + 2 Al2O3

Leaching powdered 96–97% pure silicon with water results in ~98.5% pure
silicon, which is used in the chemical industry. However, even greater purity
is needed for semiconductor applications, and this is produced from the
reduction of tetrachlorosilane or trichlorosilane. The former is made by
chlorinating scrap silicon and the latter is a byproduct of
[silicone](/wiki/Silicone "Silicone") production. These compounds are volatile
and hence can be purified by repeated [fractional
distillation](/wiki/Fractional_distillation "Fractional distillation"),
followed by reduction to elemental silicon with very pure [zinc](/wiki/Zinc
"Zinc") metal as the reeducing agent. The spongy pieces of silicon thus
produced are melted and then grown to form cylindrical single crystals, before
being purified by [zone refining](/wiki/Zone_refining "Zone refining"). Other
routes use the thermal decomposition of silane or tetraiodosilane. Another
process used is the reduction of [sodium
hexafluorosilicate](/wiki/Sodium_hexafluorosilicate "Sodium
hexafluorosilicate"), a common waste product of the phosphate fertiliser
industry, by metallic [sodium](/wiki/Sodium "Sodium"): this is highly
exothermic and hence requires no outside fuel source. Hyperfine silicon is
made at a higher purity than almost every other material:
[transistor](/wiki/Transistor "Transistor") production requires impurity
levels in silicon crystals less than 1 part per 1010, and in special cases
impurity levels below 1 part per 1012 are needed and attained.[33]

## Applications

### Compounds

Most silicon is used industrially without being purified, and indeed often
with comparatively little processing from its natural form. Over 90% of the
Earth's crust is composed of [silicate minerals](/wiki/Silicate_minerals
"Silicate minerals"), which are compounds of silicon and oxygen, often with
metallic ions when negatively charged silicate anions require cations to
balance the charge. Many of these have direct commercial uses, such as clays,
[silica](/wiki/Silica "Silica") sand and most kinds of building stone. Thus,
the vast majority of uses for silicon are as structural compounds, either as
the silicate minerals or silica (crude silicon dioxide). Silicates are used in
making [Portland cement](/wiki/Portland_cement "Portland cement") (made mostly
of calcium silicates) which is used in [building
mortar](/wiki/Mortar_\(masonry\) "Mortar \(masonry\)") and modern
[stucco](/wiki/Stucco "Stucco"), but more importantly, combined with silica
sand, and gravel (usually containing silicate minerals like granite), to make
the [concrete](/wiki/Concrete "Concrete") that is the basis of most of the
very largest industrial building projects of the modern world.[62]

Silica is used to make [fire brick](/wiki/Fire_brick "Fire brick"), a type of
ceramic. Silicate minerals are also in whiteware [ceramics](/wiki/Ceramic
"Ceramic"), an important class of products usually containing various types of
fired [clay](/wiki/Clay "Clay") minerals (natural aluminium phyllosilicates).
An example is [porcelain](/wiki/Porcelain "Porcelain") which is based on the
silicate mineral [kaolinite](/wiki/Kaolinite "Kaolinite"). Traditional
[glass](/wiki/Glass "Glass") (silica-based [soda-lime glass](/wiki/Soda-
lime_glass "Soda-lime glass")) also functions in many of the same ways, and is
also used for windows and containers. In addition, specialty silica based
[glass fibers](/wiki/Glass_fiber "Glass fiber") are used for [optical
fiber](/wiki/Optical_fiber "Optical fiber"), as well as to produce
[fiberglass](/wiki/Fiberglass "Fiberglass") for structural support and [glass
wool](/wiki/Glass_wool "Glass wool") for thermal insulation.

Silicones are often used in [waterproofing](/wiki/Waterproofing
"Waterproofing") treatments, [molding](/wiki/Molding_\(process\) "Molding
\(process\)") compounds, mold-[release agents](/wiki/Release_agent "Release
agent"), mechanical seals, high temperature [greases](/wiki/Lubricant
"Lubricant") and waxes, and [caulking](/wiki/Caulking "Caulking") compounds.
Silicone is also sometimes used in [breast implants](/wiki/Breast_implant
"Breast implant"), contact lenses, [explosives](/wiki/Explosive "Explosive")
and [pyrotechnics](/wiki/Pyrotechnics "Pyrotechnics").[63] [Silly
Putty](/wiki/Silly_Putty "Silly Putty") was originally made by adding [boric
acid](/wiki/Boric_acid "Boric acid") to [silicone oil](/wiki/Silicone_oil
"Silicone oil").[64] Other silicon compounds function as high-technology
abrasives and new high-strength ceramics based upon [silicon
carbide](/wiki/Silicon_carbide "Silicon carbide"). Silicon is a component of
some [superalloys](/wiki/Superalloy "Superalloy").

### Alloys

Elemental silicon is added to molten [cast iron](/wiki/Cast_iron "Cast iron")
as [ferrosilicon](/wiki/Ferrosilicon "Ferrosilicon") or silicocalcium alloys
to improve performance in casting thin sections and to prevent the formation
of [cementite](/wiki/Cementite "Cementite") where exposed to outside air. The
presence of elemental silicon in molten iron acts as a sink for oxygen, so
that the steel carbon content, which must be kept within narrow limits for
each type of steel, can be more closely controlled. Ferrosilicon production
and use is a monitor of the steel industry, and although this form of
elemental silicon is grossly impure, it accounts for 80% of the world's use of
free silicon. Silicon is an important constituent of [electrical
steel](/wiki/Electrical_steel "Electrical steel"), modifying its
[resistivity](/wiki/Resistivity "Resistivity") and
[ferromagnetic](/wiki/Ferromagnetic "Ferromagnetic") properties.

The properties of silicon can be used to modify alloys with metals other than
iron. "Metallurgical grade" silicon is silicon of 95–99% purity. About 55% of
the world consumption of metallurgical purity silicon goes for production of
aluminium-silicon alloys ([silumin](/wiki/Silumin "Silumin") alloys) for
aluminium part [casts](/wiki/Casting "Casting"), mainly for use in the
[automotive industry](/wiki/Automotive_industry "Automotive industry").
Silicon's importance in aluminium casting is that a significantly high amount
(12%) of silicon in aluminium forms a [eutectic
mixture](/wiki/Eutectic_mixture "Eutectic mixture") which solidifies with very
little thermal contraction. This greatly reduces tearing and cracks formed
from stress as casting alloys cool to solidity. Silicon also significantly
improves the hardness and thus wear-resistance of aluminium.[65][66]

### Electronics

Main article: [Semiconductor device
fabrication](/wiki/Semiconductor_device_fabrication "Semiconductor device
fabrication")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Silicon_wafer_with_mirror_finish.jpg/220px-
Silicon_wafer_with_mirror_finish.jpg)](/wiki/File:Silicon_wafer_with_mirror_finish.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Silicon_wafer_with_mirror_finish.jpg "Enlarge")

Silicon wafer with mirror finish

Most elemental silicon produced remains as a ferrosilicon alloy, and only
about 20% is refined to metallurgical grade purity (a total of 1.3–1.5 million
metric tons/year). An estimated 15% of the world production of metallurgical
grade silicon is further refined to semiconductor purity.[66] However, the
economic importance of this small very high-purity fraction (especially the ~
5% which is processed to monocrystalline silicon for integrated circuits) is
disproportionately large.

Pure [monocrystalline silicon](/wiki/Monocrystalline_silicon "Monocrystalline
silicon") is used to produce [silicon wafers](/wiki/Wafer_\(electronics\)
"Wafer \(electronics\)") used in the [semiconductor
industry](/wiki/Semiconductor_industry "Semiconductor industry"), in
electronics, and in some high-cost and high-efficiency
[photovoltaic](/wiki/Photovoltaic "Photovoltaic") applications. Pure silicon
is an [intrinsic semiconductor](/wiki/Intrinsic_semiconductor "Intrinsic
semiconductor"), which means that unlike metals, it conducts [electron
holes](/wiki/Electron_hole "Electron hole") and electrons released from atoms
by heat; silicon's [electrical conductivity](/wiki/Electrical_conductivity
"Electrical conductivity") increases with higher temperatures. Pure silicon
has too low a conductivity (i.e., too high a [resistivity](/wiki/Resistivity
"Resistivity")) to be used as a circuit element in electronics. In practice,
pure silicon is [doped](/wiki/Doping_\(semiconductors\) "Doping
\(semiconductors\)") with small concentrations of certain other elements,
which greatly increase its conductivity and adjust its electrical response by
controlling the number and charge ([positive](/wiki/Electron_hole "Electron
hole") or [negative](/wiki/Electron "Electron")) of activated carriers. Such
control is necessary for [transistors](/wiki/Transistor "Transistor"), [solar
cells](/wiki/Solar_cell "Solar cell"), [semiconductor
detectors](/wiki/Semiconductor_detector "Semiconductor detector"), and other
[semiconductor devices](/wiki/Semiconductor_device "Semiconductor device")
used in the computer industry and other technical applications. In [silicon
photonics](/wiki/Silicon_photonics "Silicon photonics"), silicon can be used
as a continuous wave [Raman laser](/wiki/Raman_laser "Raman laser") medium to
produce coherent light, though it is ineffective as an everyday light source.

In common [integrated circuits](/wiki/Integrated_circuit "Integrated
circuit"), a wafer of monocrystalline silicon serves as a mechanical support
for the circuits, which are created by doping and insulated from each other by
thin layers of [silicon oxide](/wiki/Silicon_dioxide "Silicon dioxide"), an
insulator that is easily produced by exposing the element to oxygen under the
proper conditions. Silicon has become the most popular material for both high
power semiconductors and integrated circuits because it can withstand the
highest temperatures and greatest electrical activity without suffering
[avalanche breakdown](/wiki/Avalanche_breakdown "Avalanche breakdown") (an
[electron avalanche](/wiki/Electron_avalanche "Electron avalanche") is created
when heat produces free electrons and holes, which in turn pass more current,
which produces more heat). In addition, the insulating oxide of silicon is not
soluble in water, which gives it an advantage over [germanium](/wiki/Germanium
"Germanium") (an element with similar properties which can also be used in
semiconductor devices) in certain fabrication techniques.[67]

Monocrystalline silicon is expensive to produce, and is usually justified only
in production of integrated circuits, where tiny crystal imperfections can
interfere with tiny circuit paths. For other uses, other types of pure silicon
may be employed. These include [hydrogenated amorphous
silicon](/wiki/Hydrogenated_amorphous_silicon "Hydrogenated amorphous
silicon") and upgraded metallurgical-grade silicon (UMG-Si) used in the
production of low-cost, [large-area electronics](/wiki/Large-area_electronics
"Large-area electronics") in applications such as [liquid crystal
displays](/wiki/Liquid_crystal_display "Liquid crystal display") and of large-
area, low-cost, thin-film [solar cells](/wiki/Solar_cells "Solar cells"). Such
semiconductor grades of silicon are either slightly less pure or
polycrystalline rather than monocrystalline, and are produced in comparable
quatities as the monocrystalline silicon: 75,000 to 150,000 metric tons per
year. The market for the lesser grade is growing more quickly than for
monocrystalline silicon. By 2013, polycrystalline silicon production, used
mostly in solar cells, was projected to reach 200,000 metric tons per year,
while monocrystalline semiconductor grade silicon was expected to remain less
than 50,000 tons/year.[66]

### Mechanical watches

Since 2000, silicon has found a new use in mechanical watch movements. Several
manufacturers of mechanical watch movements have incorporated silicon parts,
mainly in the escapements and balance wheel regions. Silicon hair-springs are
becoming more common as are silicon escapement wheels and forks. Silicon has
several desirable properties when used in these contexts; It is thermally
stable, shock resistant, and requires little to no lubrication. Ulysse Nardin
pioneered these applications, with Omega, Breguet, Patek, Rolex, Cartier, and
Damasko following.[68] Most of these parts for watch movements are
manufactured by [deep reactive-ion etching](/wiki/Deep_reactive-ion_etching
"Deep reactive-ion etching") (DRIE).[69]

## Biological role

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/20110123_185042_Diatom.jpg/220px-20110123_185042_Diatom.jpg)](/wiki/File:20110123_185042_Diatom.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:20110123_185042_Diatom.jpg "Enlarge")

A diatom, enclosed in a silica cell wall

Although silicon is readily available in the form of
[silicates](/wiki/Silicate "Silicate"), very few organisms use it directly.
[Diatoms](/wiki/Diatom "Diatom"), [radiolaria](/wiki/Radiolaria "Radiolaria")
and [siliceous sponges](/wiki/Siliceous_sponge "Siliceous sponge") use
[biogenic silica](/wiki/Biogenic_silica "Biogenic silica") as a structural
material for skeletons. In more advanced plants, the silica
[phytoliths](/wiki/Phytolith "Phytolith") (opal phytoliths) are rigid
microscopic bodies occurring in the cell; some plants, for example
[rice](/wiki/Rice "Rice"), need silicon for their growth.[70][71][72] There is
some evidence that silicon is important to nail, hair, bone and skin health in
humans,[73] for example in studies that show that premenopausal women with
higher dietary silicon intake have higher [bone density](/wiki/Bone_density
"Bone density"), and that silicon supplementation can increase bone volume and
density in patients with [osteoporosis](/wiki/Osteoporosis
"Osteoporosis").[74] Silicon is needed for synthesis of
[elastin](/wiki/Elastin "Elastin") and [collagen](/wiki/Collagen "Collagen"),
of which the [aorta](/wiki/Aorta "Aorta") contains the greatest quantity in
the human body.[75]

Silicon is currently under consideration for elevation to the status of a
"plant beneficial substance by the Association of American Plant Food Control
Officials (AAPFCO)."[76][77] Silicon has been shown in university and field
studies to improve plant cell wall strength and structural integrity,[78]
improve drought and frost resistance, decrease lodging potential, and boost
the plant's natural pest and disease fighting systems.[79] Silicon has also
been shown to improve plant vigor and physiology by improving root mass and
density, and increasing above-ground plant biomass and crop yields.[78]

## Safety

People can be exposed to silicon in the workplace by breathing it in,
swallowing it, skin contact, and eye contact. The [Occupational Safety and
Health Administration](/wiki/Occupational_Safety_and_Health_Administration
"Occupational Safety and Health Administration") (OSHA) has set the legal
limit ([Permissible exposure limit](/wiki/Permissible_exposure_limit
"Permissible exposure limit")) for silicon exposure in the workplace as 15
mg/m3 total exposure and 5 mg/m3 respiratory exposure over an 8-hour workday.
The [National Institute for Occupational Safety and
Health](/wiki/National_Institute_for_Occupational_Safety_and_Health "National
Institute for Occupational Safety and Health") (NIOSH) has set a [Recommended
exposure limit](/wiki/Recommended_exposure_limit "Recommended exposure limit")
(REL) of 10 mg/m3 total exposure and 5 mg/m3 respiratory exposure over an
8-hour workday.[80]
